Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project provides scholarships to able and financially needy students majoring in biotechnology, biology, and mathematics who transfer to four-year institutions or enter the workforce in life-science industries with a solid understanding of the interdisciplinary nature of biology and mathematics. Building on a record of successfully fostering STEM students by creating a learning community and providing intensive academic support, one-on-one mentoring, internships and research opportunities, the project is awarding approximately 125 scholarships and supporting four cohorts of scholars.

High school students with demonstrated academic potential and veterans are being recruited. Currently enrolled part-time students may be selected. An Advisory Board including faculty, administrators, students, government, and industry representatives advises the project management team. The project emphasizes supporting students through seminars, social media, student-faculty interaction, field trips to research labs and companies, and informal student interactions.

Intellectual Merit: The academic programs into which the students go are strong, and there are academic support activities. On-RAMP participants develop core competencies highlighted in 2010 AAAS "Vision and Change," including the ability to use quantitative reasoning, modeling and simulation, and an understanding of the interdisciplinary nature of science. By developing students' fluency in mathematics and introducing the quantitative tools applied to life sciences, On-RAMP is taking advantage of opportunities created by the convergence of biotechnology, biology, and mathematics.

Broader Impact: On-RAMP addresses local industry and government agency demand for biotechnology and life-science employees who have quantitative or computational biology skills. Changing demographics dictate that the rich resources of the county's increasing ethnic and economic diversity be tapped. On-RAMP is increasing the number and diversity of students from underrepresented groups in biotechnology and mathematics. Seminar topics augment existing curricula, creating better alignment with that of four-year receiving institutions, and fostering the development of bioengineering, biology-based calculus, and biostatistics courses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Montgomery College is a three-campus community college with approximately 34,000 students located in Montgomery County, Maryland.  The NSF funded S-STEM grant, On-RAMP to STEM (Retention and Achievement through Math Prowess) was written with the goals to support students with financial need (particularly underrepresented minorities) to attend Montgomery College full-time, to expose them to the interdisciplinary nature of science while emphasizing quantitative skills, and to provide academic support to ensure their success.  On-RAMP to STEM was one part of a multi-effort program to increase overall enrollments in STEM programs and improve student success at Montgomery College.

     Over the six-year grant duration, 2013-2018, STEM program enrollments increased by 29%.  Enrollment of veterans and active duty personnel in STEM programs increased by 55.6%.  Overall success for students in STEM programs increased dramatically as well.  STEM associate degree awards during the grant period increased 140% over the previous five-year period, and STEM student transfer rates increased 72.7%.

     A primary goal of the On-RAMP to STEM grant was to provide scholarships to students with financial need so they could attend Montgomery College full-time.  Students received tuition for up to 15 credits per semester for four semesters maximum.  Our stated goal in the proposal was to award a maximum of 125 scholarships.  Over the six-year lifetime of the project, 98 scholarships were awarded leaving $59,109 unused.  Of these awards, 77 went to minority students.  Scholarship recipients received strong academic support in the form of mandatory intrusive advising, supplemental math instruction and additional support through college learning centers.

     Our academic support goal was designed to ensure that scholarship recipients maintained GPA’s of at least 2.8, completed the Precalculus/Calculus course sequence with grades of B or better, and successfully graduated with an Associate’s degree or transferred to four-year institutions.  Ninety-six percent of scholarship recipients (94 out of 98) maintained GPA’s of 2.8 of higher and 92% obtained grades of B or better in the Precalculus/Calculus course sequence.  The average overall GPA of scholarship recipients was 3.60.

     The academic success of On-RAMP to STEM scholarship recipients was due in part to a required intrusive advising program.  Scholarship recipients were matched with an academic advisor in their discipline.  A total of 47 STEM faculty were recruited to serve as On-RAMP advisors.  Students were required to meet with their academic advisor twice each semester, and also meet with a transfer advisor of their choice twice per semester and document the meetings.  The project director ensured that every student complied each semester.  The project director also monitored midterm and final grades for students each semester, and formally directed students to their academic advisors if they received a grade of C or lower in any class.  We believe that this advising model, and careful tracking of students’ advisement activities, played a significant role in our students’ success both in academics and with respect to graduation/transfer.

     On-RAMP to STEM scholarship recipients were very successful with graduation and transfer at rates much higher than the institutional average.  Sixty-five scholarship recipients (66.3%) graduated from Montgomery College with an Associate’s degree.  Nineteen students (19.4%) successfully transferred to four-year institutions without obtaining a degree from Montgomery College.  As of this writing, the remaining 14 (14.3%) students are currently taking classes at Montgomery College, and are not yet eligible for graduation or ready to transfer.  Thus, over four-fifths (85.7%) of scholarship recipients have graduated/transferred to date.  The graduation rate of 66.3% is significantly higher than the collegewide rate of 36% for STEM students with similar GPAs.

     As part of their support, scholarship recipients attended a weekly seminar focused on modeling a biological process.  This program created a learning community of faculty and student scholars who explored the interdisciplinary aspects of science and the increasingly quantitative nature of biology.  The seminar theme changed each year.  For example, the fall 2017-spring 2018 seminar theme was “Mathematical Modeling of the Zika Virus Outbreak.”  In 2015-2016, the seminar theme was “Mathematical Modeling of Immunotherapy in Cancer Treatment.”  Each year students used the Vensim software package on projects to quantitatively describe and model biological processes.  Moreover, students gained experience reading the scientific literature and made presentations based on a paper they read related to the seminar theme.  Seminar participants heard from guest speakers about scientific career paths and opportunities in computational biology and big data.  Guest speakers included scientists from the National Institutes of Health, National Cancer Institute, and a graduate student from the University of Maryland, Baltimore County.

     In addition, scholarship recipients traveled to laboratories in the region such as the J. Craig Venter Institute and National Cancer Institute to tour facilities and speak with scientists.  The seminar learning community emphasized quantitative skills, the importance of internships, and interdisciplinary focus, along with providing practical experience in mathematical modeling, reading and presenting the scientific literature, and exposure to real working scientists.

 


Last Modified: 11/08/2018
Modified by: Scot Magnotta
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Montgomery College is a three-campus community college with approximately 34,000 students located in Montgomery County, Maryland. The NSF funded S-STEM grant, On-RAMP to STEM (Retention and Achievement through Math Prowess) was written with the goals to support students with financial need (particularly underrepresented minorities) to attend Montgomery College full-time, to expose them to the interdisciplinary nature of science while emphasizing quantitative skills, and to provide academic support to ensure their success. On-RAMP to STEM was one part of a multi-effort program to increase overall enrollments in STEM programs and improve student success at Montgomery College. Over the six-year grant duration, 2013-2018, STEM program enrollments increased by 29%. Enrollment of veterans and active duty personnel in STEM programs increased by 55.6%. Overall success for students in STEM programs increased dramatically as well. STEM associate degree awards during the grant period increased 140% over the previous five-year period, and STEM student transfer rates increased 72.7%. A primary goal of the On-RAMP to STEM grant was to provide scholarships to students with financial need so they could attend Montgomery College full-time. Students received tuition for up to 15 credits per semester for four semesters maximum. Our stated goal in the proposal was to award a maximum of 125 scholarships. Over the six-year lifetime of the project, 98 scholarships were awarded leaving $59,109 unused. Of these awards, 77 went to minority students. Scholarship recipients received strong academic support in the form of mandatory intrusive advising, supplemental math instruction and additional support through college learning centers. Our academic support goal was designed to ensure that scholarship recipients maintained GPA?s of at least 2.8, completed the Precalculus/Calculus course sequence with grades of B or better, and successfully graduated with an Associate?s degree or transferred to four-year institutions. Ninety-six percent of scholarship recipients (94 out of 98) maintained GPA?s of 2.8 of higher and 92% obtained grades of B or better in the Precalculus/Calculus course sequence. The average overall GPA of scholarship recipients was 3.60. The academic success of On-RAMP to STEM scholarship recipients was due in part to a required intrusive advising program. Scholarship recipients were matched with an academic advisor in their discipline. A total of 47 STEM faculty were recruited to serve as On-RAMP advisors. Students were required to meet with their academic advisor twice each semester, and also meet with a transfer advisor of their choice twice per semester and document the meetings. The project director ensured that every student complied each semester. The project director also monitored midterm and final grades for students each semester, and formally directed students to their academic advisors if they received a grade of C or lower in any class. We believe that this advising model, and careful tracking of students? advisement activities, played a significant role in our students? success both in academics and with respect to graduation/transfer. On-RAMP to STEM scholarship recipients were very successful with graduation and transfer at rates much higher than the institutional average. Sixty-five scholarship recipients (66.3%) graduated from Montgomery College with an Associate?s degree. Nineteen students (19.4%) successfully transferred to four-year institutions without obtaining a degree from Montgomery College. As of this writing, the remaining 14 (14.3%) students are currently taking classes at Montgomery College, and are not yet eligible for graduation or ready to transfer. Thus, over four-fifths (85.7%) of scholarship recipients have graduated/transferred to date. The graduation rate of 66.3% is significantly higher than the collegewide rate of 36% for STEM students with similar GPAs. As part of their support, scholarship recipients attended a weekly seminar focused on modeling a biological process. This program created a learning community of faculty and student scholars who explored the interdisciplinary aspects of science and the increasingly quantitative nature of biology. The seminar theme changed each year. For example, the fall 2017-spring 2018 seminar theme was "Mathematical Modeling of the Zika Virus Outbreak." In 2015-2016, the seminar theme was "Mathematical Modeling of Immunotherapy in Cancer Treatment." Each year students used the Vensim software package on projects to quantitatively describe and model biological processes. Moreover, students gained experience reading the scientific literature and made presentations based on a paper they read related to the seminar theme. Seminar participants heard from guest speakers about scientific career paths and opportunities in computational biology and big data. Guest speakers included scientists from the National Institutes of Health, National Cancer Institute, and a graduate student from the University of Maryland, Baltimore County. In addition, scholarship recipients traveled to laboratories in the region such as the J. Craig Venter Institute and National Cancer Institute to tour facilities and speak with scientists. The seminar learning community emphasized quantitative skills, the importance of internships, and interdisciplinary focus, along with providing practical experience in mathematical modeling, reading and presenting the scientific literature, and exposure to real working scientists.
